title: PacMan Inspired Light Shade for  IKEA SOLARVET
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi,

This is a remix from the great work made by StensethJeremy with the PacMan Inspired Light Shade. This was adapted in order to fit in the in the IKEA SOLARVET string lights.
All the work of adaptation was made with the *.stl file. Firts of all the mesh was scaled but the walls resulted too thick to iluminated properly because the leds lights aren't too powerful. In order to correct that, I made an offset of the inner walls. Finally I reduced the diameter of the socket to fix in the leds.

comments.text: These are awesome!
comments.author: StensethJeremy

author: callega

description.text:
This tiny thing allows you to fix a 5mm LED on a flat surface. Thanks to a screw system, you don't need to solder anything. You can connect several LEDs on a series or parallel circuit. update : On the new version, screws are on the sides instead of on the top, so it's nice, but a little more difficult to mount, that why I also kept the older design. Parts (for each LED) :
  • 5mm LED
  • 2x m2 8mm hexagon socket screw
  • 2x m2 square nut
  • wires
    • Tools :
  • m2 Allen key
  • Glue, blue tack or something to fix the part
  • Of course 3d printer :)

• Print the part (because of the small size, you should configure your printer to print this part as accuracy as possible) ;
  • Take a look at my splendid picture that describes instructions ;
  • fix the holder (with blue tack, glue or whatever you want).

This is an adapter meant to adapt larger holes in my design for a dop stick holder for use with smaller dop sticks. This means one holder can be printed with uniform hole sizes and used with a variety of sticks. The holder can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1705504

I have uploaded models for adapting 1/2 inch holes to 3/8 inch and 1/4 inch sticks. You can edit the .scad file to make your own in different dimensions, or use customizer to do the same and download your custom model.

This was made as part of a series featured here: http://www.protoparadigm.com/news-updates/what-to-do-with-a-3d-printer-make-lapidary-tools-and-accessories/

The dimensions of your final print may vary a bit depending on your printer calibration. Likewise, dowels or other dop sticks may vary a bit in size. For this reason, if you want a tight fit, your best bet is probably to print this part with the size you want or a little smaller (not adding any room for slop in the print) then go in and ream out the inside with a drill bit of the correct size for your stick.

Absolutely nothing, the Ada fruit trinket is doing all the job, and is acting as a micro switch
So 3 wires as usual, positive, negative and signal out. That's all.
Will upload the ultimate version, as this one is very old now...
I made the system for my P3Steel, much less pieces to print and is working great.
Regards
comments.author: tibuck

comments.text: i have a prusa i3 very much like the MK2  only difference is I have a 200x300 bed but im sure your idea can be adapted to work ! BTW I like your e3d extruder, I do think you should go though the tags for you would get a lot more hits on it  I search thingivers every so often to see what people came up with for the e3d and I never came across yours till I seen your reply post in the forums.
comments.author: Trojan3D

comments.text:
I will post the files of the new bed level system for the prusa, you can adapt the design as much as you want, is very easy.
The only thing is: i work with Solidworks, not openscad or other cad, and most of the times the files are just quick prototypes, so you will find a bit tricky to modify them, but if you are patient you will do it :-))
About the tag, i'm not sure i want more hits, people has already started asking for a lot of changes and other things, but the extruder is working great as it is, and every change in the structure would mean hours of design, and for what?
All of mine at today has hundreds of hours without a single fail, and the quality of the print is amazing, and trust me, i am very demanding!!
I am designing a new one for my new Hipercube delta(tesseract delta)which is already working but with a bowden one and same bed level system and magnetic effector rods...... and Smoothieboard, Fantastic!!!!!
Will post pictures of the printer as soon as i find the time to clear up the wiring, just for fun :-))
Best Regards

title: Teensy LC based Big Red Button

description.text:
If you've ever needed a Big Red Button, either to Go Faster or to, say, Quick Save your Fallout 4 game, here's an easy solution for you.

With just a Teensy LC (https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/teensyLC.html)
a Big Button of the color of your choice (I used these: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NPZ2028/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1)
Some M3 inserts (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01BHDXTX8/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1)
And a few M3 Screws (anything over 12MM should work)
you can have your own programmable button that can be any keyboard or mouse command you want.

I have mine set up to send an F5 key to the PC and the light slowly comes on after about 5 minutes without a quick save... this has saved my Vault 111 survivor more times than I can count, so get yours today!

My current code for the button can be found in a github repo

description.text:
Electronics Cards are very sensitve. We must protect them. Most of the users who want to start electronics using Arduino Uno. And most of the people have a Arduino Uno too. So i create a Uno Box & Breadboard Box together in only one box.

You must print Hinge by two times. Please do not forget.

You can use M2 20mm (4) screws to fix the BottomBOX to MiddleBOX

You can use M3 6mm screw (4) to fix the Hinge or you can glue to the MiddleBOX and TopBOX

print_settings.Notes:: Be deliberate about making sure your bed height is well-tuned. If your first layer is too mooshed down the dimensions won't be correct and the stencil will need some finishing. If the first layer isn't mooshed down enough it will not adhere well and you're likely to have a warped template. Low warp materials are recommended.

description.text:
These are stencils for common sizes of round and oval cabochons.

Cabochons are shaped and polished stones prepared for display or to be set in jewelry. They are typically prepared by roughly cutting a stone to shape, tracing or drawing the desired shape onto the stone, and grinding away material to shape and polish the stone according to that outline. These stencils are meant to be used in that process, for tracing standardized shapes onto the stones.

The numbers are the dimensions of the rounds or ovals in millimeters.

You can edit the .scad file or use Customizer to add text to one end of the stencil, such as your name or a company name. The stencils pictured were made for Westcoast Mining (http://www.wcmining.com/).

The prints in the picture were made with ProtoParadigm Citrene and Aquamarine Gemstone PLA. This was made as part of a series featured here: http://www.protoparadigm.com/news-updates/what-to-do-with-a-3d-printer-make-lapidary-tools-and-accessories/

Notes:

Be deliberate about making sure your bed height is well-tuned. If your first layer is too mooshed down the dimensions won't be correct and the stencil will need some finishing. If the first layer isn't mooshed down enough it will not adhere well and you're likely to have a warped template. Low warp materials are recommended.

This is a 360 Video Camera case for the Raspberry Pi 3 using a Kogeto Dot panoramic Lens. It also has threading at the bottom of the case to allow it to be easily mounted onto a tripod. You can find instructions for how to build this on my Tinkernut Project Page. To see samples, you can watch my Youtube video tutorial.

Bronze tiger from the collection of the Minneapolis Institute of Art, from 500-600 BCE.

From the object's description on artsmia.org:
'This tiger with socket clearly served as the base for an upright support of some sort. Treatment of certain details like the rope patterns around the eyes, on the socket and eyebrows, and fetlocks and the granulation pattern on the ears indicate a date around 500 b.c.'

http://collections.artsmia.org/art/1035/tiger-china

description.text:
My wife said long-stem roses were more romantic. Here is an add-on for tc_fea's excellent "Rose with stem" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84075 using Nfarrow's rose leaf http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:539491

I created a stem and a choice of a joint with or without leaves. There is also a set of leaves that can be slipped on to the regular short-stem rose.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0A (Repetier)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Recommend printing parts upright with a 2 mm or more brim. These parts have a pretty small contact area with the build plate so they have to be well stuck.

Print 2-3 of each part at a time to keep the tips and tops sharp.

The leaves are quite delicate while printing. If you have trouble with the leaves tearing, try printing at a lower speed.

I used ABS for the models in the photos.

1. Requirements

1 or more "Rose with stem" - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84075

2. Assembly

Trim any brim and 1st layer bulge from the end of the stem and glue that end into the narrow end of the joint with a little acetone or ABS slurry.

Insert your Rose with stem into the top, glue optional.

Stand back and admire.

comments.text: Nice! What are the different bases for? And do you print them in the orientation in the preview? Looks like they need to be rotated onto a circular side.
comments.author: HEAVYLIGHTS

comments.text:
I made different bases so that its "functionallity" could change.
You can use the complete cylinder with a high infill to produce weight, this way it won´t be flying around with a small breeze.
The "hollow" cylinder can be used if you want to put the mask on a stick or hang it somewhere, the orientation varies depending on the material and size you are printing, ie ABS, then you want to avoid a big surface area on the build plate.

I like many printed up belt tentioners from thingverse. Most worked fine but after a while they warped and got loose. I also had issues with them hitting the heads when they did get loose and wreck 12 hour print jobs.
These clips I designed use the existing belt tension design and add some height to the sides.

Print 100% solid.
1) Pick a set of clips based on how loose your belts are. (I used the second and third highest for most of mine)
2) Open up claw and remove pressure bolts (see pic with red text "remove") These will no longer be needed.
3)loosen one pulley (helps in evening out the tension top and bottom)
4) Place clips on sides like in ISO render. Make sure slope is facing in.They should "snap" on and stay on their own. If not double check that they are pushed on all the way.
5) Fold down claw and place an extra bolt through the extra holes in head (blue text in REMOVE.jpg) This will keep the wood from breaking under the new pressure. I learned this the hard way.
6) Now reassemble the claw per the factory instructions. 
7) Don't forget to tighten up the pulley.
8) Belt should now "Sing" if they don't try a higher clip. If you can't get the claw closed try a lower clip. The clips are in increments of 1mm in height so you may have to make your own inbetween height.
Don't worry about the upside down clips...they will be kept in place by the belt and the clip tension.

Replica of Rey's blaster from Star Wars VII with room inside to house electronics. Does not have a movable safety switch, but it does have a movable trigger. If you print it, let me know how it goes and if any changes need to be made. Enjoy! (If you want to print the wall mount it can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2755576)

Hardware required:
6 x 1-64 (1/8") Socket screws
4 x 8-32 (3/8") Button head torx screws
27 x 4-40 (1/4") Button head torx screws
1 x dowel pin (1/8" wide x 1/2" long)
1 x spring (5/8" in length, 11/64" diameter)

UPDATE
-Updated the grip files to clean up the screw holes.
-Updated Front Plate to fix missing node for barrel attachment.
10-2-2016
-Split the Safety Component into two pieces (the Safety Knob and the Safety Plate) to make it easier to print.
3-24-17
-Updated "Bottom Body" to include missing hole.

description.text:
Small Adapter to reuse the original Aluminium Cam Mounts of popular FPV Cams in Diatone Crusader Tower.

Adapter fits for mounts of these cams:

  • Foxeer HS1177 Orange: http://goo.gl/h0wpTT Black: http://goo.gl/jHsmBu
  • RunCam Eagle (used in pictures): http://shop.runcam.com/runcam-eagle/
  • RunCam Swift Orange: http://goo.gl/sm9tV6 Black: http://goo.gl/rD0IDW
  • RunCam Owl Plus http://goo.gl/pcvLup

and many other ...

These Cams doesn't fit in the Diatone Cam Mount so i want to use the original Mounts in the Tower. There was no holes where it can screwed so i decided to make a adapter for it. It first started out as a clip on thing for my glasses so i didnt have to wear a welding helmet (It was supposed to be printed with BLACK ABS so i wouldnt blind myself through peripheral vision). I know its not perfect but its an open source platform to attach to your glasses so you can add anything you want! My new plan is to make a monocular so i can increase my viewing distance. The opposite of Mr. Gadget when he zooms in on that piece of metal. (Insert video clip here)
If your using PLA save yourself a ton of editing and use MY gcode file. its tailored to PLA and works great. Just print, and clip!

title: Modified Graber i3 ATX power supply

description.text:
It is basically the same printer but it has some modifications made by me, my intention is to group all the files that I use for educational purposes (Now people can download all these files and follow my tutorials).

Here you can find the original laser cut files: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:182675#

Which was remixed from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40465

Then, the original Graber ATX laser cut files are here: https://github.com/sgraber/Graber

I used this parts:

First attempt at designing any 3D printed object. Simple design for a climbing hold - the flat sloper. Approximately 8" x 5" x 2.75". Will be tested when my printer gets here. If someone beats me to it, I recommend using a washer to attach the bolt.

08/14/2016: Original file was pulling up incorrectly in Cura by registering the millimeters as the number of inches making for a very tiny model. Fixed this. Still too large for my printbed, (202.52 x 70.31 x 127.9 mm), so I'm looking into splitting the model before printing.

08/19/2016: Made a medium-sized version that prints on my printbed with a brim. Fixed bolthole size.

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure you flip "OA case top" and "OA text" so that you don't need supports

description.text:
This is an on air sign you can put up outside your door to let people know that you are filming. Print "OA case top" and "OA case bottom" in any color you want, and print "OA text" in transparent. If you want, you could print it in white and use LEDs to light it through. That way you can leave it there and just turn it on instead of taking it down every time. Also remember to flip over "OA case top" and "OA text".

You can scale any size you want, but make sure you scale everything.

This print is on my channel! See it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VERhfWYTxbg Be sure to subscribe if you like gaming and 3d printing: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCrjPGEYoPsmMCipVC--b3XQ

Creality Cr-7

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

0.15

15%

Make sure you flip "OA case top" and "OA text" so that you don't need supports

This is a perl script that generates a solid figure of revolution, which is equivalent to a solid figure with a top surface that conforms to a single-valued function of r in cylindrical coordinates - z = f(r).

The example STL is a normalized sinc function, z(r) = sin(π•r)/π•r, but z(0)=1 over the range r:[0,5] and scaled 5:1 in mm. To get this shape:

RevolutionFigure.pl z='sub{ my ($r) = @_; $r *= atan2(1,1)*4.0; return $r==0 ? 1 : sin($r)/$r; }' r=0,5 base=0.35 e=0.005 scale=5 file=sinc.stl

The clever part of the script is that you can specify the function that you want to print by using the "z=" parameter and writing a perl lambda function for the script to draw. Ha!

Script Parameters

z is the function that you want to draw. The skeleton looks like this z='sub{ my ($r)[email protected]_; return <function-of-$r>; }' You may have to use double quotes to make it work in Windows.

r is the range of r to use in order to compute z. Make sure that z is defined in real numbers over the whole range of r, or the script will error out.

base is the minimum thickness of the figure. If you make this zero, then the figure should either be at a minimum at one end of the r range or the other, or else you will get a print that is split at any place where z is at a minimum.

e is the maximum allowable error between the print surface (after scaling) and the true surface. Expressed in mm. The smaller this parameter, the more triangles the script will draw. You can wind up with a mondo STL file if you're not careful.

scale is the scale factor, so scale mm represents a unit in r or z.

file is the file to write as STL.

b is an optional lambda function that describes the bottom. If you specify b then the base parameter is ignored. This can be useful for strictly positive z functions where you want to have the base at zero, i.e., b = 'sub{ 0; }'. If your base function is anything other than a plane, you are probably going to need to print with support.

It is possible (but a pain) to use b to print a shell rather than a solid.

description.text:
This is the part of the Real Burning Lightsaber that holds the syringe valve in place and allows the valve to be opened and closed! If you haven't seen the video already, this is what I'm talking about:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u-xHso660tA

Printed on a cheapo CTC, holes and outer dimensions account for shrinkage for that particular machine and PLA so YMMV. Have a file handy ;(

Only one "ignition piece" is necessary, the file has two spaced apart to allow them to cool down and not become a melty mess if you're just printing that part.

EDIT: Added the fritzing schematic for the ignition circuit! The parts in the schematic are just the best matches in fritzing, the actual MOSFET I used was a FQP30N06L and the LiPo battery was this: http://www.ebay.com/itm/2-TURNIGY-Nano-Tech-Lipo-Battery-1S-35C-70C-300mAh-3-7v-Lithium-Polymer-Pack-A8-/142330421529?hash=item21238de119

title: Bedmount for timelapse cameras using M4 Nut and Bolt

description.text:
Update: I added an angled bed mount if your bed is completely straight. If you try this one, please tell me how well it works. I would recommend adding some sort of adhesive or rubber to the contact area, as it could slide. I was not able to get it to stick properly.

After liking the design Antscran made, I decided to make one based on his model, but with an M4 nut and bolt instead of a printed one as I managed to break two printed bolts already.

This model doesn't go under the bedplate, but rather relies on the nut and bolt to hold it in place. The original model caused some issues where the underside would hit the printer frame, seen here.

Here is a stability test, in case anyone is interested about the results. The print stopped when it was almost finished, but the video is only to show stability.

In order to replicate this you'll need a camera holder. I used this one.

comments.text: Can I use PLA for this?
comments.author: derailed

comments.text: Yes, just make sure not to screw it in too tight. Also make sure to angle it away from the heated bed, as PLA isn't as heat resistant as some other filaments.

author: chev383

description.text:
Hidden wall outlet safe:

Print the Outlet_Safe.stl file.
Using a real receptacle, remove the mounting screws from the yoke (metal ends).
Use a real receptacle outlet plate and screw the plate to the receptacle using a plate screw. (I used real receptacle and outlet cover so it matches the house exactly)
Use two rubber band and attach them as shown in the photo by looping them around the two rubber band mounting holes.
Loop the ends of the rubber band between the real receptacle plate and the metal yoke to hold the receptacle and plate to the wall box as seen in the picture.

If your plate is too loose, use smaller rubber bands or rotate the outlet and plate a few times knotting up the rubber band and it will fit snug.

I made two holes in the box to screw the box onto a wall stud.

I made this very simple but it is very effective and kinda cool too!

Printer:

Ultimate Mendel Max

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

101x55x53

Hidden Safe Idea

I wanted a wall outlet safe and started by using the Single Outlet Box
by garyfack, published Nov 12, 2014 and tweaked it for my needs. Adding holders for the rubber bands and holes to mount the box to a wall stud.

To make it look real, I used a real receptacle outlet and plate to match my house.

My printer prints fairly fast speeds. It is a MendleMax and I built it from scratch about 4 years ago and have it tweaked out fairly well so it prints pretty fast. 1% in an hour seems way too slow for just about any printer I have ever messed with.

description.text: Shaped like a mini brick the "Blok Bot" is the building block of bots. With the heart of a Raspberry Pi Zero the Blok Bot can be programmed to be a friend, assistant, teacher,listener,etc. You can program vision recognition, voice interactions, and responds to voice commands. IOT Robot that can be used for any project.

Printer:

Flash Forge Creator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.27

Infill:

.10

Notes:

The Resolution works well within the .20 to .27 range.
Sanding + Xacto knife may be used.

Designed using 123D SketchUp

The designed was based off of Polylines in combination with extrude function.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/qK8KOanF7B8" ></iframe>
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/FhlLlKaqm5I" ></iframe>
Heres a demo of BlokBot +MiniplanV5 Intergration voice Recognition
Project: BlokBot Pi

Overview & Background:

This project helps gain an understanding of designing a simple Blok Bot and learning how to program with different Speech API on the raspberry pi.

Objectives:

Students will learn to use Raspberry Pi Zero.
Students will learn to create/use Schematics.
Students will learn to Solder
Students will learn imaging.
Students will learn Python coding
Students will understand speech recognition API
Students will experience hands on construction.
Students learn robotics.

Audiences:

The grades, ages, or skill levels that would be appropriate for this Project.
4th grade+, Age 10+, Skills in Soldering

Subjects:

Subjects in programming in Python, and Bash. Basic understanding of speech recognition.

Skills Learned (Standards):

3D Slicing
Designing
3D Printing
Motor Skills
Complex Thinking Skills
Innovation skills.

Stuff Needed

Raspberry Pi Zero
PI NOIR Camera V2 or Pi Camera V2
Silicon 30AWG wires (variety of colors is recommended)
(optional not needed)20x SMD Tactile Pushbutton Key Switch Momentary Tact 2 Pins 362.5mm
Raspberry Pi Zero v1.3 Camera Edition
Raspberry Pi Zero v1.3 Camera Cable
Edimax WiFi USB
32 or 64gb card
PowerBoost 500 Charger - Rechargeable 5V Lipo USB Boost @ 500mA+

NTSC/PAL (Television) TFT Display - 1.5 NTSC/PAL (Television) TFT Display - 1.5" Diagonal PID
2m 30AWG White Silicone Cover
2m 30AWG Black Silicone Cover
2m 30AWG Red Silicone Cover
2m 30AWG yellow Silicone Cover
2m 30AWG green Silicone Cover
2m 30AWG bluewSilicone Cover

Steps Above are the parts needed to build a Blok Bot Print out all 6 layers Here we will modify the Zero4U module by soldering out the battery holder and replace with 30mm red/black 30awg wire. Next shorten the backside of the camera cable that connects to the Raspberry Pi side Much shorter backside On layer 1 tape the back of the camera to the inside of Layer1 Connect The raspberry pi zero to Zero4U Stuff the camera cable between the pi and Zero4U On the Raspberry Pi, solder the wires to both displays. Schematic shown. At the 4th Layer add the battery and the Poowerboost. Finally set the screens on top of the battery and the powerboost, make sure to put electrical tape behind the screens. Finally add the special case

Step 1:
Lets use Sample.wav to test speaker
alsamixer
Step 2:
Press F6 to list all soundcards
example
│ │ │ │ │ │
│ │ │ ┌───── Sound Card ──────┐ │
│ │ │ │- (default) │ │
│ │ │ │0 bcm2835 ALSA │ │
│ │ │ │1 USB PnP Sound Device │ │
│ │▒▒│ │2 USB Audio Device │ │
│ │▒▒│ │ enter device name... │ │
│ │▒▒│ └───────────────────────┘ │
│ │▒▒│ │▒▒│
Based off the soundcard hardware selection
aplay sample.wav -c2 -D hw:0,0 (Speaker)
aplay sample.wav -c2 -D hw:1,0
aplay sample.wav -c2 -D hw:2,0
Step 3:
Lets configure the Microphone
arecord -d 2 -D plughw:1,0 -r 16000 -f S16_LE sample.wav (Tiny Microphone)
Step 4:
Once everything works lets install espeak
sudo apt-get install espeak
sudo apt-get install espeak python-espeak
Step 5:
In terminal type aplay -l to make a note on the USB audio device as the output

Step 6:
sudo nano /etc/asound.conf
And set the code below for Espeak to work correctly. Save it
defaults.ctl.card 2
defaults.pcm.card 2
defaults.timer.card 2

Alsamixer command helps to for tuning

sudo apt-get install libboost-regex1.49.0

sudo apt-get install git-core
git clone git://github.com/StevenHickson/PiAUISuite.git
cd PiAUISuite/Install/
./InstallAUISuite.sh

if you encounter "error while loading shared libraries: libboost_regex.so.1.49.0: cannot open shared object file: No such directory"

sudo apt-get install libboost-regex1.49.0

Voicecommand -e

Voice command setup config file
To setup custom custom commands from words

voicecommand -s

There are two files included in the site, one is an .sh file and one is a python file.
API used is Wit.Ai, you can use any API you want, I used Wit.API as an example. If you want to use Wit.Ai just change the token Key.
Make sure both files have 777 permissions.

Duration:

1 hour for printing.
1 hours for assembling and programming.

Preparation: Rubric & Assessment:

What implementations can the student add to further improve it?
What did the student learn for building this?
Any troubleshooting problems the student encounter?

Handouts & Assets:

https://www.raspberrypi.org/learning/getting-started-with-picamera/worksheet/

description.text: First off this is a Work In Progress! I wanted to make a 5mm LED light holder for these high output LED's. It started as a single LED then I thought I would group 6 together. My goal is to design a high output emergency strobe that will contain all the electronics inside. I plan on using yellow led's but I only had the red for right now. It is extremely bright and couldn't take a direct shot of the face with the led's lit because it swamped out the camera. Future aspects will include a removable stand, waterproof cover and the electronics. So if your interested stay tuned! If you just want to use the design for another project that's fine but give me credit. BTW using my FFCP the sockets that the led's go into is a very tight fit so it holds the LED's perfectly. I uploaded a single LED holder and also the 6 LED holder also.

Eu fiz essa máquina para a minha faculdade. A idéia era usar ela só pra fazer PCB.
Como o orçamento era curto eu "enxuguei" como deu. Usei mdf, algumas peças eu imprimi na minha 3D, a breakboard eu que fiz.
Pra PCB essa mecânica atende super bem. Porém ela trabalha com mais materiais, testei MDF, madeira, alumínio, acrílico e ACM, PVC.
Com alguns materiais mais duros você tem q ter um pouco de paciência, mas da pra usinar.
A placa de controle usa porta paralela. Uso o Mac3 pra controlar a máquina.
Se você quer uma máquina um pouco mais robusta aconselho fortemente a trocar o sistema do braço e usar uma guia apoiada, algo parecido com o sistema da base.

title: Parts for Adding Third Z Screw to D-Bot

description.text:
NOTE: Please see the update and the end for description of the latest configuration.

I wanted to add a third lead screw to my D-bot. I also wanted to drive all the z-screws with one stepper, with GT2 belts to keep everything in sync. I added another 2040 extrusion to the front of the D-bot bed and made adapters to hold a 608zz bearing in the motor mount. I also made a motor mount that holds a 608zz bearing at the right position to line up with the lead screw bracket on the bed. These parts can be used in a few different ways.

Mount the z motor on the front of the D-bot, and use the extended_lead_screw_bracket on the bed. It is designed to line up with the motor.
-or-
Mount the 3rd_z_screw bracket on the front of the D-bot, and use a regular lead screw bracket (from the D-bot files).

The 608_z_adapter can be used to replace a stepper motor with a 608zz bearing.

The ramps_idler_cover is just something I used on my ramps box to let me mount some flanged bearings as idlers. The GT2 belts need to be tensioned somehow.

I don't consider this a full-blown, print-and-install solution. You still have to find pulleys, belts, bearings, hardware, and do some experimentation, but if you're in the middle of all that, you might find some of these parts useful.

Update: The first pictures I put up show a screw and bearing mounted at the front of the machine. The last picture I put up shows the motor mounted in front. This allowed me to make the standoffs for the idlers shorter and therefore more stable. I also added a model for a nut holder for the standoffs. It is designed so you can pause the print and insert a 3mm nut - you have to create the pause yourself, though. The nut holder has a tab that slides in the slot when the idler is mounted, so it's easier to tighten and adjust.

Update 9/9/16: I have just finished upgrading my D-Bot to a 300x300 bed, and re-did the lead screw configuration. The third screw is now mounted at the back of the bed instead of the front, and all three screws are driven by a separate motor, instead of having one of the screws driven directly. This means the motor can have a GT2 20T gear while the screws have 40T, for more precision and torque. The separate motor is mounted in the same mounts as used on the original D-Bot and there is and adjustable plate with idlers to help tension the GT2 belt.

The idler wheels used here were created using thing 16627 and then modified in tinkercad to hold 623 bearings, which are what I had handy. Again, I'm making these parts available in case someone is trying to put a setup like this together, but they'll probably still have to figure out and fabricate a few things for their specific machine.

I tried to list this as a remix of the D-bot by spauda01, but no matter how I tried, the remix search function would not pick it up. For those interested, it is thing 1001065.

I Have yet to figure out why that happened, because my printer is printing fine with other files. I tried putting it through Meshmixer to look for gaps that had to be repaired, but could not find any.

2nd problem: One of the pictures I uploaded shows severe stringing in the center of the box. This is in fact NOT stringing, but seems to be a very fine layer that I cant see in the model. I hope that someone can take this and make it work, or help me with some constructive criticism so I can fix it.

title: Finding the Area of a Hexagon

description.text: Students are shown a 3D model with 6 equilateral triangles that form a hexagon. They are then asked to prove that the hexagon is regular and to find its area.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

To make this model I used the Tinkercad polygon shape generator. I put in 3 sides to get the triangle and unchecked the pointed box. Under the size specifics dropbox I clicked on length of side and made that 50 mm. I made the thickness 20 mm. Then I used Velcro dots to make the triangles stick together. Another option is to use magnets. I used these magnets found at a craft store: https://www.sbarsonline.com/sbars/p-8122-mag-208.aspx.

Magnet sticking together with magnet sticking together with velcro

Students will see how to find the area of a hexagon based on their pre-existing knowledge of finding the area of a triangle. The purpose of this activity is for students to see a hexagon is made of 6 equivalent triangles and to find the area of the hexagon they just need to find the area of one triangle then multiply by 6. Skills Learned (Standards): CCSS.Math.Content.6.G.A.1
Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems. CCSS.Math.Content.7.G.B.6
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms. CCSS.Math.Content.8.G.B.7
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.

• To introduce the topic show students a clip from Sonny With a Chance (season 1, episode 5). In it Sonny has been doing bad at math and she has a big geometry test coming up. In one scene Zora tries to explain geometry with a model. She says that a hexagon is made up of six triangles. The model has six triangles, each a different color, that are stuck together to form a hexagon. She pulls one triangle off and explains that if you find the area of one triangle you can find the area of the hexagon. The clip can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dXHdXpd3Te4.

  • Show students this printed model that is similar to the model used in the television show. You can print just one copy to pass around or have several for students to play with.

  • Have students prove that this is a regular hexagon.

  • Ask students to find the area of the hexagon.

  • Ask what other shapes they can make using only equilateral triangles. Can they make a triangle, a rhombus, some other shape? Then find the area of each of these shapes.

• Area of Triangles
  • Area of Geometry
  • Pythagorean Theorem
One Day

For this activity students should be familiar with hexagons and equilateral triangles and know how many degrees are in each. Students should also know how to find the area of an equilateral triangle and The Pythagorean Theorem.

Here is a sample rubric to use with this activity. Question 3
Sum of interior angles of hexagon=720 (1)
Each angle = 120 (1)
Angles in equilateral triangles = 60 (1) Question 4
Draw perpendicular (1)
Perpendicular splits side length in half (1)
Using Pythagorean Theorem to find height (2)
Area of triangle (1)
Area of hexagon (1) Question 5
Make triangle and find area (2)
Make rhombus and find area (2)
Make other shape and find area (2) Total 15

If students need a refresher on how to find the area of an equilateral triangle they can watch the Khan Academy videos on these topics. https://www.khanacademy.org/math/geometry/basic-geometry/advanced-area-with-triangles/v/area-of-an-equilateral-triangle. For a review of how to find the angles in a regular polygon students can view this website:
http://www.mathsisfun.com/geometry/interior-angles-polygons.html.

author: kd8fnl

title: vintage walking robot 3d printed Foki robot

description.text: You can 3d print this walking robot with lit eyes for very little money. It operates from a single AA battery. The robot was inspired by the 1960's robot game made by DAISH a Argentina company. In the game the robots eyes would lit if you picked the right answer. This robot uses a low voltage / low curent Dc gear motor from SolerBotics , the GM7. And it uses the circuit board from a dollar store solar yard light to boost the 1.5 volts up to LED voltage levels. When you strip down the solar light keep the battery contacts as they will snap in to the battery holder that is printed inside the upper body part.

Printer:

Flash Forge Dreamer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

standard medium setting

Infill:

15 %

Notes:

The head was printed with supports and the crank leg linkage was printed with a raft other than that you do not need supports or raft. I used PLA and normaly print at about 210c on a heated bed of 60c.
The ears are printed as flat disc's, then I use a heat gun to warm theem up and press them in to the final shape. If I had printed the ears in the final shape it would require a raft and supports and would change the print time from 7 minuet's per disc to about 20 minuet's and then you would have to try and remove the supports and raft with out breaking the ear. Then there would be clean up time removing the supports ruff spots. So thermal forming the printed dis was so much faster and easyer.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MLs4uk6J-A8" ></iframe>
I used Design Spark Mechanical to do all the 3d part designs.

comments.text:
Your robot is "Oh-Tay" with me! I love it. Now I gotta make one. Right now I am working on the Kongotronic 3000 Time Defender robot clock. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38444
Once that is done then I can start on this one. It might be a while though, both are a little more involved than just printing out a little figurine.
Keep up the good work!

author: kd8fnl

description.text: This activity is for a geometry class. Students choose a 2-dimensional object and then discover the volume formulas for stacking copies of that object. They then are given a model that splits the cube into 3 pyramids. By looking at this model they come up with the pyramid volume formula.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

I used Tinkercad to design the squares that stacked. I used 123D Design to split the cube up. First I used polyline to get a triangle on one of the cube faces [figure 1]. Then I extruded the triangle to take it away [figure 2]. Next, I turned the object and did the same for each side [figure 3]. You need 3 copies of this pyramid to fit together to make the cube.

To get these 3 pyramids to stick together a few options I thought of is to use Velcro dots or magnets [figure 4]. I used these magnets found at a craft store: https://www.sbarsonline.com/sbars/p-8122-mag-208.aspx.

figure 1 figure 2 figure 3
CCSS
Project: Discovering Volume Formulas Students will use 3D printed objects to help them visualize the volume of various objects. Students will come up with several volume formulas.

First, ask students to choose a 2-dimensional object and print 5 copies of it. Alternatively, you can save class time by having these already printed or give students cardboard and scissors to make the shapes. Students figure out the volume formula for the 3-dimensional object created by stacking the 5 copies and share their formula with the class. Next, show students the model with 3 pyramids forming a cube. They use this model to come up with the formula for volume of a pyramid with a square base and then generalize to a pyramid with any base.

• HSG.GMD.A.1
  • HSG.GMD.A.3
  • HSG.GMD.B.4
This activity will take one to two days.
Students should have already studied two-dimensional objects, such as squares, rectangles, and circles. They need to know the area formulas for these two-dimensional objects.

Here is a sample rubric to use with the worksheet.
Question (points)
1 (2)
2 (4)
3 (3)
4 (2)
5 (4) Total 15

Students can be given an area formula sheet, such as the one found here:
http://www.mathsisfun.com/area.html

author: kd8fnl

description.text: Students learn about the Caesar Cipher and the Vigene ̀re cipher. They practice encoding and decoding messages using a decoder ring.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

First I opened the decoder ring found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14891 in TinkerCad. Then I added a rectangular prism and put a hole in the center so that the letters would be visible. Then I made the ring a hole and cut it away from the box [figure 1]. Next I cut out the middle parts, leaving a little part going up on the bottom so to hold the part in place [figures 2 & 3].

figure 1 figure 2 figure 3
CCSS

Project: Cryptography: Sending Secret Messages Students get an introduction to cryptography. They learn two ciphers and practice encoding and decoding messages using a decoder ring that is 3D printed. Students will learn what cryptography is and get some practice sending and receiving messages. Students learn the Caesar Cipher and the Vigene ̀re cipher and how to use them.
CCSS.Math.Practice.MP1 Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
CCSS.Math.Practice.MP5 Use appropriate tools strategically.

Students are introduced to the Caesar Cipher and then they practice decoding a message. They think of why this cipher doesn’t work well. Then they learn the Vigene ̀re cipher and practice decoding a message. Students then figure out how to use the decoder ring with the Vigene ̀re cipher. Finally, they encode a message and trade with another group to decode their message. As an optional extension, students figure out how these ciphers relate to modular arithmetic.

• Math.Practice.MP1
  • Math.Practice.MP5
This activity should take one day.
No background is needed for this activity. For the extension students should know modular arithmetic.

Here is a sample rubric to use with the worksheet.
Question (points)
1 (2)
2 (2)
3 (2)
4 (3)
5 (6) Total 15

description.text: This is a bracket to mount the TAZ 5 power supply vertically on the side of the printer just above the electronic control box. Make 4 of these and mount them directly to the back of the power supply with 4mm screws in the existing threaded holes in place of the flat head screws that hold the sheet metal case to the power supply unit inside the box. Uses 5mm screws and aluminum extrusion nuts to mount to the printer frame. I suggest you use lower profile heads on the 5mm bolts (Pan head rather than typical SHCS) to avoid possible slight interference with the bolts on the printer carriage. You may notice that I have also changed where the cord going to the electronic control box exits the power supply (opposite side) compared to the original design and I added a little 120V outlet box to the front side under the power switch. These are mods I made to clean up the chord routes and allow me to have local 120v power to the MatterControl Touch tablet.These are not necessary for this mounting of the power supply to work

Kids love to personalize their desks. This project allows them to do just that, while learning some design skills, with a custom designed, 3D printed desktop name.
I created this thing using Tinkercard, and if working with elementary students new to design software, I encourage you to do the same.
NGSS CCSS

This lesson, intended to introduce upper elementary students to 3D design and desktop fabrication, could possible be one of the most memorable back-to-school activities of all time! Students share interesting facts about themselves as they create their own customized nameplates, which they can proudly display throughout the school year. Objectives:
Students will learn the use of a design program, I recommend Tinkercad, while creating a custom nameplate for their desks. This lesson can also lead to some inspiring writing and presentation skills! Skills Learned (Standards):
NGSS: 3-5-ETS1-1
CCSS: (4th) LITERACY.W.4.2, (5th) LITERACY.W.5.2

• Introduce the lesson by sharing your own custom nameplate, explaining the significance of each design element. For instance, on the example above I would cite the forest as one of my favorite place to go, robotics as a favorite hobby, and doughnuts as a favorite food.

  • Students then complete the graphic organizer to record and/or draw some of their favorite things. This activity can also be done for table groups as a way to build teamship as they come up with a group name and complete the graphic organizer with mutually favorite things.

  • Using the graphic organizer as a starting point, each student will write an essay introducing themselves to the class. These can be read to partners, within table groups, or to the whole class.
    • Extension- Have students create short presentations in which they share facts about themselves and their design process.
  • Introduce students to Tinkercad, or your design program of choice. Give students the time to complete the tutorials and play a bit before diving into their nameplate design. I like to limit the overall dimensions (or if you've covered volume yet, go that route for an added math challenge!) to ensure a reasonable printing size. For reference, my example nameplate is 100 mm (w), 35 mm (d), and 30 mm (h), with a volume of about 52 cubic cm. I encourage not limiting student nameplates to a single shape or profile so long as they are within the overall limit for size/volume.
    • If these are the students' first design it is important to allow them to perform a few small practice prints, such as merging two shapes, if time and material allows. Note- With new designers it is important to do a quick check of their work lest you end up printing many piles of plastic "spaghetti"!
  • Once all nameplates are displayed on student's desks make sure to invite your buddy class or an administrator for a visit to see all of the amazing design knowledge your students have gained (and to justify why you have a 3D printer available to elementary students)!
5-10 sessions

This lesson is intended to introduce students to 3D modeling, so no experience is necessary.
The graphic organizer included with the thing files above will help students brainstorm what to include on their nameplate.
See the suggested rubric in the thing files above for some assessment ideas.

If you choose to frame this lesson as a getting to know you activity, here is a list of chapter books on friendship to consider for whole class read-aloud or small reading groups. http://www.scholastic.com/parents/resources/book-list/families-relationships/friendship-chapter-books

author: chev383

title: Hayward Valve Spider Gasket for SP0714T Backwash Valve
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My backwash valve started leaking on my pool filter. When I called the local shop they told me the gasket is part of the valve assembly and would cost over $100 to replace. I searched high and low for a replacement gasket and the best I could find is $67 for the assembly. All this for a simple gasket!

I sat down and drew up a gasket for the valve key, it fits perfectly! You may want to secure it in the channel with some RTV silicone just to be safe. Be sure to lube it with petroleum jelly when you install it back into the valve body. The gasket is keyed with 2 nubs.

Use a full-flex filament at .2mm layers with 100% infill and voila! A gasket that doesn't exist for purchase!

Enjoy!

MakerFront i3PRO

description.text:
So I bought a 12864 Display LCD 3D Printer Controller for my printer. I received it and it works just fine. (beyond the fact it doesn't have the adjustment potentiometer for the screen and the push button is the tall variant. Since the button is taller I needed to digitally drill a hole to make room for the taller button.

The hole I made at the bottom is 5.0mm diameter and 3.2mm deep.

Update 1: V2
So 3.2mm wasn't enough
V2 hole is 5.0mm diameter and 4.0mm deep

Update 2: V3
Before printing V2 I decided to reduce the base from 2mm to 1mm and with the extra room I also decided to increase the hole depth to 4.2mm.
V3 hole is 5.0mm diameter and 4.2mm deep (3.2mm deep from cut base)
Note the 4.2mm depth is starts at the full 2mm base not the 1mm base.
Source zip file updated with V3

Files

This contains my Inventor .ipt files and .STEP exports.

description.text:
My print volume is only 150mm in the Z axis, so the GramiPhone horn was hard to print. It would have required a lot of support. This is a 150mm tractrix-shaped horn for the GramiPhone.

As uploaded, I had to glue the horn into the GramiPhone stand to make it fit without drooping. If you want to fiddle with it to make it press fit properly, I have also uploaded the python code that I used in FreeCAD to draw the cross section. Maybe a diameter of 4.2mm will work better than 4.1mm. You can use the python code to create a wide variety of horns, like a megaphone or what-have-you. Here is how you use the python:

  1. Start FreeCAD and open a new Part Design.
  2. Create a sketch in the YZ plane with no offset and not reverse direction.
  3. Copy and paste Tractrix.py into the python console. If you can't see the python console choose View|Panels|Python Console.
  4. Wait a long time for the cross section to draw. When it's finished, there will be a lot of vertical and horizontal constraints. So many that the green drawing will be obscured behind the red constraints.
  5. Close the drawing.
  6. Revolve the drawing about the vertical axis 360°.
  7. Choose the revolution in the Combo View and export it to STL.

N.B. After step 4, you can delete the bulk of the drawing and only keep the top section if you want to test the fit of the horn into the stand.

description.text:
These are corner pieces designed to use for making a target stand that uses 1"x2" lumber. I used the cheap pine 1x2's, labeled as use for porch deck railing, that you find at Lowes/Home-Depot (actual dimensions are 0.75" x 1.5"). The holes that you push the wood into have a tapered ridge inside them so that you achieve a tight fit as you put it in. Cut your wood to any size you like to customize the size of the target stand.

I included two STL files. One is the full size item, the other one is trimmed slightly to fit in the Printrbot Play (small build platform).

Enjoy!

description.text:
I have recently purchased a 2016 Creator Pro by Flashforge. I had a hole list of upgrades ready to be printed when I noticed that the new Creator already has many of them:

  • a baffle for the left extruder to blow air when printing PLA
  • the door now opens laterally
  • the filament is secured
  • the handles are now covered

Printing ABS is fine out of the box for normal prints. When however I tried to print tall objects is less than ideal room temperature conditions I had some splits.

I've brewed my own beer for some time and if I learned anything is that temperature control makes all the difference.

Since I now had a 3d printer, instead of cutting and making an MDF cupboard I decided to build something to fit an old hair dryer and control it using a spare STC1000 I had.

On the right of the printer, i fitted the two boxes as per the pictures. The hair dryer was one of those small 220V models. I took it completely appart and kept the bare bones of it but unless you are confident with you electronics I would advise against. It took me a while to fire out how exactly all the wires are connected.

The holes in the Hair Dryer box are specific to my model but I'm sure you would be able to adapt it to your models. Sketchup files included. Mind you that a Sketchup export is likely to have inverted triangles and non-manifold issues. I correct those in Netfabb.

The system works really well. The only con is that it is bloody noisy. I mean LOUD!!! However the printer is in a spare room right next to our bedroom and can't hear it at night which is good. I can though imagine that if I had to work next to the printer I would probably smash the contraction into many small pieces.

I'll upload later a comparison of the same object printed in ABS, one heated one not. Mind you, those are quite big boxes, with thin walls and not a lot of infill. Other not so challenging prints were OK without active heating.

I now keep the system at 55C. The temperature probe of the STC was glued to a patch of neoprene, adhesive velcro, and stuck to the Z carriage at the back. There the read temperature is the one at bed level.

Let me know how it goes for you. Happy ABS printing.

FFF files for QIDI Tech Printer. These setting will get you close to a setup but additional tweaking is necessary because every printer is different.

6/1/17 Just updated the files with some changes to improve printing. Added pictures of my Benchy and Marvin, Benchy PLA, Marvin ABS. The Benchy took me 3 times to get right and used no heat on bed.

comments.author: Frutolo

comments.text:
Interesting to assume, that this design is copied. The switch is different, the Cable Output is different, the sides of the Object aren't the same. Thats like to say, that every Car is copied, by another, because it has wheels. And the Idea is so obvious, that I as example would have made something like this by myself if I hadn't found it with the right switch.
So don't get mad because someone had the same Idea (it kind of funny, because normally the people get mad on the Internet, because someone has an other opinion).
Btw, I like both of your designs and only took this, because i have an fitting switch by my side.
Greetings Lippifuss
comments.author: Frutolo

comments.text:
so where should i start... the switch is actually the same, just other dimensions, the cable output is the same (i´ve got 2 versions), the sides look pretty similar, and the way how you fit the sides on the power supply are 1:1 the same( ok one nut hole is rotated like 20°). And that car comparison...nah, i don´t think thats the same thing.
I´ve never said he totally copied my part 1:1... but if he says he never saw it, i don´t belive him, specially when i see how he designed the fixtures of the sides. But whatever...

title: Marlin / Glenfield Model 60 Barrel Picatinny Rail Adapter

description.text: ok so im bringing some new life into my old Model 60 by Marlin. Anytime you upgrade a rifle there has to be rails right!! so with zero options i could buy for it i designed a Rail system for it.i Have included 4 Designs, one is just the Bottom rail and the sides and top are smooth, One is same as first but has a 12mm cut out in the top to allow the original Iron sights to be used. The 3rd is a Tri-Rail design leaving on the top without rail. The 4th is same as 3rd just with the same sight channel for the iron sights. The idea is that whatever accessory you put on the bottom will hold the entire system to the gun when tightened down (mine works fine this way) but if placing lasers or exact equipment on i have provided 3 holes to secure the rail to the gun insuring it will not move (This is also handy if your mounting a bipod as they tend to generate alot of force when opening and closing at least my spring designed bipod did).The Rail System is 80mm long and should cover without hendering loading.im calling it a night tonight i post pics of it on my gun torm Happy Shooting!!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

comments.author: Lobotomy

author: Ambeos5

description.text:
I have a problem - it's difficult to demonstrate a 3D printer to your guests - you show them the printer, send a small print, and .... it will be ready after they leave.

So I designed this model with the explicit purpose of being able to completely pint it before everyone get's bored and moves on.

This model takes 9 minutes according to Cura's estimate, in reality, on my printer, it takes 12 minutes (not including warmup)

This model is tiny, the features of this model are probably just about the smallest you can print with a 0.4mm nozzle

Because the features are so small this model tends to break after a while, especially the arms fall off - but I simply don't have the space to make the arm connectors bigger. (fixed in V2)

Print with no supports and no infill

Designed with SketchUp, fixed with Microsoft 3D Builder, sliced with Cura, printed on a Robo 3D R1+

Update

Version 2 fixes the two major problems in the first model: the arms that keeps falling off and the ugly holes in the parts of the face that are supposed to be flat - in order to do this I had to remove the tapered edges from the head and body, this got me an additional 1.6mm I used to make the clearances in the head and shoulders bigger.

comments.text: I had some problems with drooping filament on the back of the legs when printed without support (though possibly my settings), but a fantastic quirky 1 piece design that I very much like.
comments.author: 3dprintedbutt

comments.text:

Thanks for that, will post a picture of my small army of robots soon!

Enjoy!

Hello!
This is just something i have been working on in the interests of learning more about programming and designing machines. It is a two axis cnc table driven by two nema 17 stepper motors. The linear transmissions are 8mm trapezoidal screws and 8mm aluminium axles with linear ball bearings. The frame is held together with 8mm diameter threaded rods. There are at least one microswitch used as a limit switch per axle. Other parts needed are m3 screws for switches and some axle couplings, in my case 5mm-8mm. I used this with an arduino mega and an adafruit motorshield v 2.3. This is just a prototype platform that can be repurposed for whatever 2 axis desktop gadget one might need.

description.text:
Apprendre en s'amusant!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nxrAihSe8s&feature=youtu.be
Nouveau petit système engrenages.
Mon premier. Avec 4 roues dentées identiques.
J'ai pris un gros module volontairement . 2,5
Dp = m x z
Dp = 2,5 x 16 (16 dents)
Dp = 40
L'engrenage est très solide.
J'ai mis des freins à lamelles ressort sur les grands axes, pour une articulation plus rigide.
Trois roues en place = blocage !
Quatre roues en place, ça tourne.
Facile à imprimer, permet de s'amuser, il n'y a aucun jeu dans les pignons.
Vous pouvez imprimer à une échelle plus petite si vous voulez.
Vous pouvez continuer avec plus de roues si vous voulez.
